image.altText: A woman with short hair smiles with a bull terrier resting its head on her lap in a living room with white shelving.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian state law has the weakest protections for people relying on assistance animals, and discrimination reports are growing. Those affected say considering legal action to access public spaces and necessary services is exhausting.

title.children: 'Incredibly outdated' assistance dog laws leaving people in limbo

image.altText: A long-haired man looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Blaise Christopher Baddeley and Dane Ronald Pyke have been found not guilty of murdering Dean Jupp at his north-west Tasmanian home in 2022. The pair have been found guilty of aggravated burglary and other charges.

title.children: Not guilty verdict for two men accused of murder in north-west Tasmania

image.altText: A young boy with a gold shirt and a mullet plays a silver horn instrument as an older gentleman helps him follow the score.

props.synopsis: This northern Tasmanian band will celebrate its 146th birthday but with the average player aged in their 70s, the band is looking to secure its future. It's teamed up with a local primary school, offering free tuition in the hope some of the students will gain the skills to join in.

title.children: This brass band is offering free tuition to bring in a new generation

image.altText: Image of a man in protective clothing holding a big rack of raw sausages.

props.synopsis: Feral deer populations are booming in Queensland, damaging farms and costing millions, but some are turning them into a business opportunity.

title.children: One solution to the out-of-control feral deer problem â€” eat them

image.altText: Salmon farm location map 4

props.synopsis: If you've travelled along Tasmania's coastline, you may have spotted collections of black circular pens floating just offshore and thought 'what are those?' They're salmon farms â€” and there is a lot of them.

title.children: How many salmon farms are there in Tasmania â€” and who owns them

image.altText: Tasmanian federal electorates 2025 graphic.

props.synopsis: All eyes will be on whether the Liberals can flip Lyons on election night, but could there be other surprising contests in Tasmania? Labor is hoping for a Braddon surge, while one of its ministers could be looking over her shoulder.

title.children: Tasmania's state of play: the toss-up seat, the minister's challenge, and Labor's long shot

image.altText: Colourful pencils on a desk in a childcare centre.

props.synopsis:
Imagine having to book a childcare place not just before your baby is born but before it's even conceived.

That's what some families in Tassie are resorting to.Â 

Along with the rest of the nation a myriad of issues plague the industry intended to care for our nation's most precious assets.Â 

Will politicians promises to ease the cost of access to childcare be enough to solve the industryâ€™s broader woes?

Featuring the ABC's Families reporter Fiona Blackwood.

Get in touch, email us: tassiecast@abc.net.au

title.children: Can election promises fix Tassie childcare crisis?

image.altText: Flock of chickens in a pen.

props.synopsis: The egg shortage is considered a possible motive after chickens were plucked from a flock of birds at a Hobart school.

title.children: Egg shortage possible motive after chooks stolen from school

image.altText: Buddhist monks walk past a collapsed building

props.synopsis: Myanmar's isolated military junta chief, Min Aung Hlaing, declares a state of emergency in all affected areas and says he expects the number of casualties to rise further.

title.children: Myanmar death toll passes 1,600 after strong earthquake, 3,400 injured

image.altText: Peter Dutton, wearing a yellow high-vis very, pauses while speaking

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's claim, so early in a contest we're told has an unusually large number of undecided voters, that Anthony Albanese cannot win in his own right has more than just a whiff of arrogance.

title.children: Dutton asked reporters a question of his own, but it might come back to bite

image.altText: A trolley of grocery store items, including toliet paper, tampons, Weet-bix, white sliced bread, instant coffee, eggs and milk.

props.synopsis: The government vows to set up a taskforce to investigate how to best make it illegal for supermarkets to price-gouge customers, despite the ACCC's inquiry failing to confirm price gouging was happening.

title.children: Labor commits to outlaw supermarket price gouging if re-elected

image.altText: Generic photos of apartments, balconies

props.synopsis: The migration "surge" is a major election issue, but official figures say numbers are already falling, with a big hit due in a couple of years.

title.children: Both major parties want less migration. The numbers say it's already falling

image.altText: Andrew Gee sits in the House of Representatives

props.synopsis: Federal MP Andrew Gee's Facebook account has been caught impersonating a disgruntled voter and praising the politician for his stand against "dirty tactics" by an opponent.

title.children: 'The good guy!' MP full of praise for himself in social media blunder

image.altText: Wide shot of a flooded paddock, a person in the distance walks knee deep along a  barbed wire fenceline

props.synopsis: As floodwaters slowly ease for some parts of western Queensland, other towns are bracing for the peak.

title.children: Race on to save towns as record-breaking western Qld flood moves south

image.altText: A flag with the colours of the rainbow flying on a flag post.

props.synopsis: Utah has become the first state in the US to prohibit flying LGBTQIA+ pride flags at schools and all government buildings.

title.children: Utah becomes first US state to ban pride flags in schools, government buildings

image.altText: Gout Gout and Lachlan Kennedy hit the line in the 200m at the Maurie Plant Meet.

props.synopsis: Gout Gout may have finished second to Lachlan Kennedy in a thrilling 200m at the Maurie Plant Meet in Melbourne, but the 17-year-old took valuable lessons away from the defeat.

title.children: 'Fuel to my fire': How Gout Gout will learn from loss to Australian rival

image.altText: A photo of a faded photo of a baby with "Kim, Hyun Ah" written across the bottom.

props.synopsis: South Korea's Truth and Reconciliation Committee's new report reveals some of the fabrications and falsifications that allowed 20,000 children to be adopted out abroad and names some of the agencies responsible.

title.children: Calls for Australia to investigate its Korean adoption past

image.altText: Graphic of someone falling into a phone head first.

props.synopsis: We may think smartphones are responsible for distracting us, but a new study suggests the devices aren't to blame, it's how we've been trained to use them. Â

title.children: Glued to TikTok? Ditching your smartphone may not break the habit

image.altText: asio jfk

props.synopsis: Determined to hide Australia's secret version of the CIA from the public, ASIO kept a lid on its role in the JFK assassination probe. Â

title.children: The public didn't know Australia had its own deep state â€” ASIO kept it that way

image.altText: A car crash scene with police officers.

props.synopsis: Police say the crash scene in Rowville, in Melbourne's south-east, was discovered by another motorist in the early hours of Sunday morning.

title.children: Two teenagers die after crashing allegedly stolen car in Melbourne

image.altText: Marlin Stutzman sits at a desk.

props.synopsis: As American producers lobby Donald Trump to put tariffs on Australian meat imports, a Republican cattle-rancher takes the fight to the US Congress.

title.children: Republican rancher introduces bill for 70pc tariff on Australian Wagyu

image.altText: View of the front of a white building in London, with a white car parked outside and plants by the door

props.synopsis: The storied studio â€” where many of the most famous film scores of all time were recorded â€” has re-opened this week after a refurbishment.

title.children: Abbey Road's Studio One reopens following renovation

image.altText: A woman wearing a yellow top looks down at her smart watch, which has a graphic of a red heart above it with numbers circling.

props.synopsis: HRV has long been used by elite athletes to dictate their training schedule and it has now become a "buzzword" among the broader community.

title.children: How HRV, a popular smartwatch stat, can help maximise your workout

image.altText: Jezzie in hospital with her family

props.synopsis: Jezabella shares her struggle of being diagnosed with a medical condition so rare, only eight other Australians were known to have it.Â

title.children: 'School years in a hospital bed': Growing up with a rare condition

image.altText: Muslim woman offering prayers during Ramadan

props.synopsis: Mercy is key in Islam, especially during the holy month. Here's what that means for Muslims and those outside the faith.

title.children: In a world of conflict, Ramadan's message of mercy is a poignant reminder

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson throws his hands up in the air in frustration

props.synopsis: Ah, my favourite part of the week: watching you make a fool of yourself. It's time to play, HARD! Â

title.children: In the mood to embarrass yourself? It's trivia time

image.altText: Cathy Freeman beams at her 2000 medal ceremony. Bruce McAvaney smiles with greying hair

props.synopsis: Following this week's unveiling of the Brisbane 2032 Olympics plan, we took a dive into the archives to relive, in the words of Bruce McAvaney, one of Australia's most memorable sporting moments.Â

title.children: Freeman's 'incredible' 400m victory retold by the man who called the race

image.altText: Man with grey ponytail and age lines on his face stands in front of palm trees and looks into the distance

props.synopsis: Kevin Whitby was driving home from a regular gym session, listening to a radio interview on sudden cardiac death. Fifteen minutes later, he had a heart attack. With the interview ringing in his ears, he went straight to hospital and was soon having life-saving surgery.Â

title.children: Kevin's time was 'almost up' but a chance message changed his life

image.altText: A worker dressed in a white jump suit uses a tablet to record items lying on a table.

props.synopsis: For five days a specialised "body farm" was transformed into a training ground for a multi-disciplinary exercise bringing together law enforcement agencies, defence personnel and forensic specialists from across Australia.

title.children: 'Body farm' helps train next generation of first responders

image.altText: Professional plumber working on a sink.

props.synopsis: Tenancy laws in Australia differ between the states and territories, but there are common approaches to getting things fixed in a rental that may help.

title.children: Experts on when renters can be reimbursed for repairs and maintenance

image.altText: A woman teaches girls with head scarves in a classroom.

props.synopsis: A March 31 deadline could see more than a million Afghans forced out of Pakistan and back to a country already buckling under crisis.

title.children: More than 1 million Afghans could soon be forced out of Pakistan

image.altText: An excavator and three people in a field.

props.synopsis: A private search for clues relating to the presumed abduction and murder of Joanne Ratcliffe and Kirste Gordon, who disappeared from Adelaide Oval in 1973, begins in South Australia's Mid North.

title.children: Search underway 52 years after girls disappeared from Adelaide Oval

image.altText: Statue of Pope John Paul II in front of chuch in Gosford.

props.synopsis: Dozens of NSW Catholic school principals will travel to Europe as part of a Jubilee "pilgrimage" later this year, but the 10-day trip has been branded "tone deaf" and "unjustified".

title.children: Europe pilgrimage for Catholic school principals 'tone deaf'

image.altText: Susan Prior and Danielle Macdonald on the mysterious Scribbly Gum Island of The Last Anniversary.

props.synopsis: The Last Anniversary is one of Liane Moriarty's earlier novels, and the Nicole Kidman produced TV adaptation drew Australian rising star Danielle Macdonald home from Hollywood.

title.children: Why the latest Liane Moriarty adaptation was so difficult to film

image.altText: Reed Mahoney and Jack Todd of the Bulldogs celebrate in the middle of the field

props.synopsis: The Canterbury Bulldogs will end round four of the NRL with the outright lead of the competition, completing a 32-year first in the process.

title.children: Bulldogs complete 32-year first, Cowboys want explanation on sin bin
